Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: An Anthropological Investigation of the Relationship between Values, Land Use Decisions, and Market-based Mechanisms

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This research will focus on how private landowner values and land-use decisions relate to market-based mechanisms. The research will take place in the Bellbird Biological Corridor (CBPC) located in western Costa Rica, an appropriate setting for the work as this is a mixed-use planning region designed to encourage sustainable development through market-based mechanisms including nature tourism and payments for environmental services. Market-based conservation programs can improve some indicators of ecological health and rural livelihoods, but the mischaracterization of landowner values can have the paradoxical effect of increasing landscape degradation.

The research integrates the nonmarket valuation method of a stated choice experiment with ethnographic data from semi-structured interviews and focus groups to arrive at a comprehensive understanding of the relation between landowner values, land-use decisions, and the ecological integrity of the landscape. Geographically weighted regression will be used to examine the strength and variation in biophysical and socioeconomic drivers of forest growth and relate this information to national and local sustainable development goals.

By combining quantitative and qualitative methodologies, this research will intellectually contribute to understanding how market economics impact human well-being. Through its attention to spatial scale, it will demonstrate how individuals and communities position themselves to interact with market-based mechanisms. The broader impacts of this research extend to environmental education, tourism regulation, and payment for environmental services programing activities being organized within the CBPC. It will also catalyze a new initiative between the University of Georgia and the Bellbird Biological Corridor to foster training opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students across the region.

POR.DRECONTENT:
My dissertation research examines the impact of market-based conservation mechanisms on private land use decisions in the Bellbird Biological Corridor of Costa Rica. In Costa Rica, nature tourism and payments for environmental services are market-based conservation mechanisms that remunerate landowners for conserving forest cover on their land. These mechanisms have gained international attention in conservation circles over the last 30 years as organizational effort has shifted from protecting parks and reserves to sustainable development across multiple-use landscapes. These mechanisms are designed to promote ecologically beneficial private land use decisions by targeting the monetary value of land uses. However, there has been little research to understand how landowners va  lue land uses and conservation practices. In my research I investigate how landowner values vary across the Bellbird Biological Corridor and the extent to which market-based conservation mechanisms engage with landowner values to foster sustainability.

In the data collection phase of my research, I spent 14 months living in Monteverde, Costa Rica, a town located within the Bellbird Biological Corridor. I interviewed 87 landowners across the study area and mapped their farm boundaries. Farm mapping occurred with the help of a local field assistant. The interview included open-ended questions designed to elicit cultural and individual values for particular land uses and conservation practices. It also included a stated choice experiment, an economic valuation technique, designed to measure preferences for conservation farming practices and the monetary value associated with those practices. I participated in farm production activities with a subset of landowners. Extensive immersion in the study area included participation in local meetings with development associations, farmers' cooperatives, and conservation organizations. This wealth of contextual knowledge provided an important complement to the interview and choice experiment data.

I have drafted my dissertation and I will be defending in April to graduate in May of 2016. My results indicate that landowner values are not always in line with monetary values, and that market-based conservation mechanisms may undermine value systems critical for promoting sustainable land uses. I also found that landowners with increased market exposure had a preference for market-based conservation mechanisms, while those with decreased market exposure tended to reject the economic incentives and land uses associated with market-based conservation mechanisms in favor of maintained autonomy and preservation of traditional agricultural uses. I further found that market-based conservation mechanisms in Costa Rica promote conservation primarily via encouraging farm abandonment, and are often economically inefficient. Payments for environmental services, for example, are preferred by individuals who already have forest cover on their land, suggesting that the program tends to pay landowners for behaviors that would occur in the absence of payment. Furthermore, my data indicate that efforts to make the program more “market-like” to improve efficiency may be insufficient. Finally, the net increase in forest cover in the study area, coupled with farm abandonment and dependency on tourism revenue, raises concerns about sustainable development. I have written a manuscript style dissertation and, upon graduation, will be submitting three manuscripts to top peer-reviewed journals for publication. Within 2 years of graduation I will make all data publicly available as per my data management plan.
